Line 20: Line 20:
The drivers' champion is determined by a point system where points are given according to finishing placement and laps led. The season is divided into two segments. After the first 26 races, the 12 highest ranked drivers are [[Seed (sports)|seeded]] based on their total number of wins and compete in the last 10 races with the difference in points greatly equalized. This is called the Chase for the Championship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shavemagazine.com/cars/090601|title=All About NASCAR|publisher=[http://www.shavemagazine.com/ ShaveMagazine.com]}}</ref> In 2009, [[Jimmie Johnson]] became the only driver to win four consecutive Sprint Cup championships.
The drivers' champion is determined by a point system where points are given according to finishing placement and laps led. The season is divided into two segments. After the first 26 races, the 12 highest ranked drivers are [[Seed (sports)|seeded]] based on their total number of wins and compete in the last 10 races with the difference in points greatly equalized. This is called the Chase for the Championship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shavemagazine.com/cars/090601|title=All About NASCAR|publisher=[http://www.shavemagazine.com/ ShaveMagazine.com]}}</ref> In 2009, [[Jimmie Johnson]] became the only driver to win four consecutive Sprint Cup championships.
â
The series holds strong roots in the [[Southeastern United States]] with half of its 36-race season in the former [[Confederate States of America|Confederate States]]. However, it has grown to become one of the six most popular [[Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada|professional sports in the United States]]. The [[Daytona 500]], its most prestigious race, had a television audience in the U.S. of about 16 million viewers in 2009.<ref>[http://www.jayski.com/pages/tvratings2009.htm Jayski.com] 2009 NASCAR Sprint Cup TV Ratings' Retrieved August 21, 2009</ref> Previously, races have been held in [[Canada]], and exhibition races were held in [[Japan]] and [[Australia]].
+
The series holds strong roots in the [[Southeastern United States]] with half of its 36-race season in that region. However, it has grown to become one of the six most popular [[Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada|professional sports in the United States]]. The [[Daytona 500]], its most prestigious race, had a television audience in the U.S. of about 16 million viewers in 2009.<ref>[http://www.jayski.com/pages/tvratings2009.htm Jayski.com] 2009 NASCAR Sprint Cup TV Ratings' Retrieved August 21, 2009</ref> Previously, races have been held in [[Canada]], and exhibition races were held in [[Japan]] and [[Australia]].
Sprint Cup Series cars are unique in automobile racing. The engines are powerful enough to reach speeds over {{convert|200|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, but high weight makes for poor handling. Their bodies and chassis are strictly regulated to ensure parity, and electronics are generally spartan in nature.
Sprint Cup Series cars are unique in automobile racing. The engines are powerful enough to reach speeds over {{convert|200|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, but high weight makes for poor handling. Their bodies and chassis are strictly regulated to ensure parity, and electronics are generally spartan in nature.
